title: Mini-MPCNC (1/2 EMT Variant)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mini-MPCNC (1/2 EMT Variant)

We consider this is a bit of a work in progress (we will be building 12-15 of these before spring). We started with the MPCNC files for the 23.5 mm (or 3/4 EMT) version. We scaled either by 75% or 80% depending on whether a part had bearings (626 bearings) or not. The parts with bearings were scaled by 80% and almost all other parts were scaled at 75%.

This Mini-MPCNC is not really intended to be used for subtractive manufacturing (or at best very light duty). The design intent would be to hold a drag knife, a pen, a plastic material extruder, and perhaps a laser.

We would like to extend a huge thanks to the team at Vicious Circle for their outstanding work in creating the MPCNC.

There is a discussion topic in the Vicious1.com forum under
[Builds and Things Built] called [Smaller MPCNC based on 1/2 EMT].
http://www.vicious1.com/forum/topic/smaller-mpcnc-based-on-12-emt-tubing/

A Bill of Materials is provided in a PDF file called 0_5EMT_MPCNC.pdf

A BOM of the printed parts with time & materials is provided in a PDF file called print_BOM_mini_mpcnc.df

Further Acknowledgements to:

Molly Carton, Ashley Combs, Josh Hamel, Eloise Perrochet, Duane Storti,
and Ben Weiss

Printer:

Flashforge

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

35-50% (see Print_BOM)

Notes:

Shells: 3
We started with MPCNC files and scaled most of them and redesigned those that required redesign using Rhino3D.

comments.text:
If you are an OCD type, then print the mirrored pieces. If not, then don't (and it will assembly just fine). The biggest issues is the pieces that hold the belts, will not be symmetric and that may be noticeable. As for the nut traps (on the xy-xyz carriage), the original MPCNC
had several nut traps depending on what size nut use purchased for the drive rod. {note: we are now recommending that you put the drive nut on the bottom position for the xy-xyz carriagle rather than on the top as per original MPCNC}. If you are talking about the Z-axis nut traps, we offer two different styles - the original and a new one which ISN'T a nut trap. You should tap the new one and it will act as a nut to hold the universal mount. Also, you will notice the slots (that is the bottom), the slots are for a screw driver to aid you in alignment inside of the pipe. {Our techs don't not like the original part and they designed the new tapped part}.

description.text:
Hi Everyone,
I really wanted to make a Dolly for my RC 1/14 Truck.
So I designed a good portion.
Please Note: You will also need the 4 x arms from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480358 and you need 4x washers (That are there to print) . You will need to buy 2x leaf springs that you can get on eBay.
You will also require a good portion of the screws and parts from any 1/14 trailer. Please see image on parts. I used a good portion of 3mm screws and nuts + I used hot glue.
I have also included snapshots of the Tamiya manual which describes how to put parts together.
-- Please Note: the 1st Rail is 20CM (200mm). As my printer only prints that long.
---- YOU WILL NEED TO DRILL HOLES AS NONE HAVE BEEN DONE SO YOU CAN PUT WHERE EVER. ----

7/1/17 - I have just uploaded photos of completed dolly before i painted and tied up and changed wiring.

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I only used rafts on the support piece.

How To Build
  1. Take 20CM (200MM) Rail + 40MM Rail and attach using 2 x Connecting Plates (Glue, Screw - Up to You) (I Glued mine)
  2. Take 2 x Support plates and the parts from the trailer and put where you want on the railing (Some where on the 200MM one). You will need to drill holes etc. You will need 4 x Washers if you are going to use 3D Printed arms. (You need 4 x Arms)
  3. Add as many support parts as you want (that will fit)
  4. At the end of the 200MM Rail put 1 x Rear Top piece.
  5. Take 2 x 50MM Rails and 1 x Support parts.
  6. Screw / Glue the support part to the end of the rails.
  7. Glue / Screw the 50MM piece to the end of the 200MM rail (Where the Top piece is)
  8. Attach the Connecting Bar to the to front (the 40MM piece)
  9. Attach the Top with connector peice to the the top between the 40MM and 200MM Rails.
  10. Use the connecting light plug for your truck etc.
  11. Connect the hitch to the hitch board using 3mm screws.

description.text:
I liked crooksUSA's remix, but wanted something that would fit on my printer well, so I created this re-mix.

It mounts on the right side, to the top screw that clamps to the front part of the enclosure.

UPDATE - I just created "V2", which should be able to be printed vertically, without support. I'm printing it now to check... ;-)
Ok, so I printed the V2 model without support, and it does print well vertically, but has a bit of slop at the bottom of the overhangs since they're a bit of an extreme angle. So I'll put together another version with a less aggressive overhang. But even though this has that issue, it does print out, and is only cosmetic, IMHO. (And I'm using it now!) I'll post the pics I took sometime soon...

Printer:

CTC Dual

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print with supports as there is a 2mm channel for the sides to overlap the edge of the printer as a clamp (since only one screw is holding it to the printer - no drilling is required).

**NOTE - The "V2" version should not need support if printed at a low enough layer height to be able to print the overhangs well. I uploaded it here, and am test printing it now.

Mounting the holder...

Look at the printer from the Right side. Remove the top-left screw (the one that clamps the front face to the right side, just below the 45 degree angle) and place the screw through the hole in the bracket and re-attach it to the printer.

Note - You may or may not need a longer screw - I was able to get it to grip the threads and re-use the existing screw and washer.

If you are anything like me, then you are always loosing your gas card for the pre-pay meter.  Ours always takes on a life of its own and can end up buried in one of several draws or cupboards.  
I made this to stick on the inside of a cupboard door so that I can always find the card.  
There is a centre support in the slot to aid printing, just cut it out when printed.

title: Universal Dual 30mm Jumbo Glue Stick Holder

description.text:
I liked MPoindexter's FT5 Gluestick Holster, but after I printed it out, I noticed my Jumbo Glue sticks didn't fit. (Mine are 30mm round, his design is apparently designed for 28mm round sticks)

This is scaled up to fit the 30MM Elmer's Jumbo "Washable School Glue" sticks that I have, and I also 'flattened' the back out to make it universal to mount on any flat surface, plus added two more screw mounts for more mounting flexibility. ;-)

Printer:

CTC Dual

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.27mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The resolution and infill isn't all that important - the finer the resolution, the better the mounting holes will be defined. Other than that, the layer height and infill percentage are completely up to you.
I mounted mine to the right side of my printer, on the bottom-right screw that mounts to the 'floor' plate. I used the center screw only, and no washer. It snugs up nice and doesn't move. (See Pics)

So i'm using this trick (since i'm a kid) to have light at 360 degrees when only having a flashlight or smartphone and a bottle of water (transparent). It's perfect for camping, when you want to play cards (while drinking some booze...), in your tent with your wife (or dog for the luckiest) or just for your kids in their room. (I don't have kids, dogs or wife so if they don't like it i'm not responsible)

Anyway i just got my hands on a Flashforge Dreamer and decided to design something light foldable, small enough to fit in my backpack. It can work with every type of phones if it have a flash.

This is my first design so it as some flaws. Only one actually: If you print it you will have to cut the top of the bottom part (not the bottom of the top one!). I had to cut 0.1 mm on each side of the "pins" to make it fit nice and tight (If you know what i mean). I will fix and update it later when i will have more time.

-RAFT : NO NEED
-SUPPORT : NO NEED
-PRINTING TIME : 6-7H in total (a rat ate my filament so had to reload it...)

Layers: 0.2000 mm
-TOP SOLID LAYERS : 3
-BOTTOM SOLID LAYERS : 3
-SHELLS : 4
-INFILL : 15%

Cheers,

Yann

ps: I choose wooden filament and a concentric External Fill Patern (I like it this way).

title: Prusa I2 cooler for e3d V6

description.text: Its FINALLY HERE!!. For all of you like me that are still using a prusa mendal I2. There is finally an option for a good print cooler design. I would like to emphasize that I am not the original designer for this cooler. Credit goes to Zeppelinum/ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:120249. However I did do the modifications necessary for this to fit on a prusa mendel I2 with a wade extruder and a 3 bearing x-axis carriage. I have printed this myself and am currently installing it on my printer as I make this post. I appoligize for any "crudity" of the model due to the fact i was having a massive amount of mesh failures when exporting from tinkercad. This is the best i could get done without making one from scratch. However I assure you it prints fine and fits together well. I have added "rails" in order to try to make sure that the print cooler can only move freely on the vertical axis. I have also added 2mm holes in the print cooler for set screws in order to lock the 2 pieces together and to clamp the heat sink shroud onto the heat sink itself. Once I have this completed and on my printer I will update with the outcome.

comments.text: I have had problems with my design in that the print cooler slides off of the heat sink cooler. If anybody else is having this issue do what I did and find a height you like it at and glue it into place. Sorry guys.

title: Having Myself a Merry Little Christmas

description.text: For this ornament I set out to combine various 3D design, 3D scanning, and 3D printing processes to create a single seamless ornament. All programs used were open-source, aside from the scanning software, including: SketchUp, Shapeshifter, Meshmixer, and Netfabb Studio. I scanned myself using an Xbox Kinect and Artec Studio.

Print all parts using the JasonJFerguson_ornament-Final.stl or the JasonJFerguson_ornament-Final.thing files. Assemble the components by melting scrap pieces of ABS (same color as your model) in some Acetone to make ABS glue. Be sure to use a glass jar when dissolving the ABS. Use the following settings for your print:
High Resolution
50% infill
3 shells
.10 mm layer height
no support
no raft For a quicker print, lower the resolution to Standard and use the following settings; Standard Resolution
50% infill
2 shells
.20 mm layer height
no support
no raft
(Note: These settings shorten the time for the full print from over 6 hours to just over 3.) I also included separate .stl files for each individual part if you want to experiment with different color combinations OR if you want to put a different topper on your ornament...may be kind of strange hanging me on your tree.

author: jasonjferguson

title: Affordable Prosthetic for people without Fingers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This multipurpose hand prosthetic is designed for people without fingers so that they could perform some basic activities. While there are plenty of such projects online, they are mostly either too simple or are too expensive and too complex for cheap mass production. As an Indian, I have designed this especially for people living in poor countries where this prosthetic can be distributed very cost effectively by health agencies.

The arm clamp is detachable so that you can make your custom clamp according to your comfort and needs.
Note: The model I printed came out quite bad because of my broken printer. I have made quite a lot of design changes. However, I haven't had the time to test those changes. So it would be amazing if anyone could print this and give me some feedback in the comments.
With this, people without fingers should be able to:
Use Pens and Pencils
Use Cutlery
Use Toothbrush
Added features:
Hold cups
Hold bags
Use touchscreens
Use 4mm Hex tool bits and interchangeable screwdriver sets
I got the inspiration after stumbling different assistive devices on Thinigiverse .
I am also uploading a version without the cup holder.

Printer:

Self Made

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

At least 20%

This arm is a mixture of many simpler designs available on thingiverse. I have tried to add as many as functionalities to this one arm as possible.
I used CATIA V5 to model this arm.

Making the stylus

In order for the stylus to work, it should be conductive and be connected electrically to your body. There are many ways to do that which can be found in this wikihow article:
http://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Stylus
I will describe here the simplest way and my favourite way to do it:
1) Take a small piece of aluminium foil.
2) Attach it with a piece of wire.
3) Wrap this around the stylus tip and stick it with tape.
4) Extend the wire to the clamps.
5) Add a small piece of metal to the other end of the wire.
6) Whenever you want to use, attach this metal piece to your body and the stylus will start working

comments.text: As a designer, I realize that whom ever it was that took the time to design this item must have a very close relationship to somebody that has dealt with the struggles that this item addresses. However, it is now totally possible to get a complete prosthetic, with moving fingers and thumb for vary little and sometimes even free. A world-wide organization, http://enablingthefuture.org makes this happen.
comments.author: LeeSouth

print_settings.Notes:: Enjoy.!

description.text:
I wanted a controller and made one.

Was printed on a 220mm x 220mm bed. Object is 210mm.
Printed at .20 layer height with .22 first layer for good adhesion on heated bed with .3mm nozzle diameter.

Electronics are:

NRF24L01 with antenna via ebay
arduino pro mini
3.7v lipo at 750mah with connector
Gimbals where from ebay, but you can customize the ones from hobbyking for use
Potentiometers where b10k cut down slightly for trim control
switches are on/off/on
led for power in the middle
safety pull up switch for center power on
Posts for body where aluminum from local hardware store. Can use model ones.

Works very well and nice 2.4ghz TX.

Hope you enjoy.!!!

Printer:

Custom

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20/.22 first layer

Infill:

20% Rectilinear

Notes:

Printed at .20 layer height
20% infill, rectilinear
first layer was .22 height
was printed with E3D nozzle @ .3mm with fan for PLA
1st Layer bed temp 70, other layers 40
Was designed on SpaceClaim 2016 and Rendered with KeyShot
All files are repaired!

Enjoy.!

This is a rack enclosure that will fit 6" components such as these:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2084736
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1957436
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905998
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1840021

More to follow, together with a customizable component
The code is now also available here: https://github.com/KronBjorn/SixInchRack

It is designed for the 20x20 extruded aluminium profile, but a profile can also be printed.

Use a thread cutting tap in the nut-less trap and printed profile.

1U is 14mm
The front plate is 15.5cm
The distance between two profiles is 11.5cm

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Print with three outer layers top/bottom/side
Layer thickness 0.25
Infill 33%
PLA works fine

Since finding metric screws in local hardware stores can be a challenge in the States, I ended up using:
8 x 3/4 wood screws (tapered head)for the top and bottom, with printed 2020 posts. These are not super tight, but hold together fine on my print. Since they extend past the first hole in the post, you can use one of the machine screws as a set screw for them.
4 x 1/2 wood screws (tapered head) for holding the cases together (I cut off a portion to fit the handles on the cases)
6-32 x 1/2 machine screws (round head) for securing the side panels and cases to the rack posts

title: Rostock max clip on T10 LED

description.text:
Used the clip shape from the LED mount created by int2str, but redrew it to fit T10 LED bulbs. These 5630 LEDs are very bright, seem to run fairly cool, and the mount is low profile. Solder leads to the back of the bulb before installing into the housing. Exits for the wires to the inside and out both sides. I just drilled a small hole next to the extrusion to pass the wiring through. Best printed in TPU, could work in other materials but I haven't tested fitment except in TPU. I drew them to use on my Rostock max, but should work equally well for any other 1"aluminum extrusion.

You can find the LED bulbs I used here (not an affiliate link)

These bulbs have bridge rectifiers on them so it makes no difference which pad you solder positive or negative to.

title: Hovering Disk - DIY 3D Printed - Frictionless Motion Experiment

description.text:
The Hovering Disk is a 3d printed device, which demonstrates almost frictionless motion. The air coming from the balloon is moving through a small whole to the bottom of the disk. At the bottom it is distributed all-over to all sides. This constant air stream prevents the disk from touching the ground and the disk therefore starts hovering.

See the disk in action:
https://youtu.be/wl0n9UZzOhQ

To demonstrate the hovering effect use even surfaces like glass or flat tables.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

No Rafts no support, make sure the print surface is even and does not have any damage.
I designed this using Autodesk Inventor, check the video from the description for more information.

Teaching about kinematics in physics always needs to include talking about friction. What it is and where the energy goes to. Demonstrating moving objects with friction is easy, since friction is everywhere. But how to demonstrate moving objects with (almost) no friction is hard.
Use the "Hovering Disk - DIY 3D Printed - Frictionless Motion Experiment" to demonstrate movements with almost no friction.
This project acts more like a lessen opening than the main content. Demonstrating the effect of almost no friction will give you a nice introduction into the mechanics of moving objects.

title: Customizable Helical Crayford Focuser for Newtownian Telescope

description.text:
This is a helical Crayford Focuser for use with an amateur Newtonian telescope. It is made for 1¼″ eyepieces, but can be customized easily to accept 2" eyepieces. The mounting angle of the ball bearings is 5°, thus for each full rotation the draw tube (outer diameter D=35mm) moves inward or outward by tan(5°)πD= 9.6mm, which allows for very fine adjustments of focus. The angle can be customized (check out the customizer app) to allow for coarser or finer alignment.

The design consists of two parts: the actual focuser, and an adapter to attach the focuser to the cylindrical tube of the telescope. The shape of the latter depends heavily on the telescope, or may be not necessary at all for certain telescopes.

Besides the 3D printed parts, the following items are necessary to complete the focuser:

  • 7 machine screws M3x25mm, one screw M3x16mm, preferably made of stainless steel.
  • 3 screws M3, variable length, for mounting the adapter to the telescope
  • M3 nuts & washers
  • 6 (stainless) steel ball bearings type 623
  • The draw tube. It should have an inner diameter of 1 1/4" or 32mm, and an outer diameter between 34mm and 35mm. The length depends on the position of the intermediate image in the telescope relative to the position of the focuser, and the eyepieces used with the focuser. In most cases it should be shorter than my version, which is fairly long (125mm, with 60mm usable travel). For suitable materials of the tube, I tried aluminum and stainless steel, but plastic may be possible, too. The roundness of commercially available steel/aluminum tubes is not sufficient for smooth operation of the focuser, so I improved the roundness by getting the outer diameter of the tube reduced slightly with a lathe in a nearby metal workshop.

I used the following OpenSCAD libraries for the design:

  • https://github.com/openscad/MCAD
  • https://github.com/JohK/nutsnbolts

Update: The customizer shows more meaningful parameters now.

Printer:

SLS

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

The focuser was printed by http://www.rapidobject.com, using their cheapest SLS material (PA 2200).
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" mozallowfullscreen="None" webkitallowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/194152965" ></iframe>

comments.text: I want to try printing this one, but on my telescope, the location of the 3 screws is different.  On yours, you've got one screw on the longest side and the other two screws 60 degrees off of that.  On my scope, one screw would go on the shortest side and 60 degress off that.  Would it be possible to get a version with the holes rotated around 90 degrees from their current positions?  I'm downloading Fusion 360 and can try to make the attempt myself (Solidworks just isn't in my budget), but didn't know if that might be an easy change.
comments.author: kidder

comments.text: Hi, in fact it is quite simple to change the orientation. I added a variable in the Open SCAD source file and made it available for the customizer. Simply click on "Open in Customizer" and change telescope-adapter/Tube Screw Orientation to 90 degrees. This will give you a new model with the correct positions for your telescope. Depending on your printer, you may want to change some other variables there, too. If you actually print the focuser for your telescope, please share a photo!
comments.author: kidder

comments.text: Thanks much!  I'll try to print it next week.  I've got to order the bearings and modify the scope a bit.  The existing scope (Astromaster 130) has a reuleaux triangle shaped focuser (instead of circular) and a plastic housing to match it
comments.author: robsch

comments.text: You're right, the screws are not perpendicular to the OTA. This is not ideal, but sufficient. Actually, the original focuser that came with the telescope had the same orientation and position of the screws, and the manufacturer didn't mind either. But obviously this becomes more problematic with smaller OTA diameters.
comments.author: kidder

comments.text: Well, I took the existing focuser off this weekend to get the measurements for the screws and found that they are not an equilateral triangle.  So they aren't ever going to line up...
comments.author: robsch

comments.text: Too bad! If you get the correct measurements, you could still try to change the model in OpenSCAD. Maybe the existing focuser is shaped in a way that makes it easier to measure the distances of the screws than on the OTA.
comments.author: kidder

description.text:
This are parts to enable mounting an adjustable platform to the vertical piping of an Obutto home cockpit. Used in this instance to mount an Orbweaver next to a throttle, made for Star Citizen so one can use proper flight and FPS inputs at the same time and transition blindly between them, very well suited for VR.

When not in use, simply pull out platform upwards and the rest of the assembly can be stuck under the Warthog throttle platform.

Printer:

E3D Bigbox Dual

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Settings depend heavily on the used material, anything which doesnt bend too much will do. Depending on printer's precision (or lack thereof) it may be necessary to tidy up the hole where the platform goes through, it is an intentionally tight fit.
Recommend 5 solid layer on top and bottom as well as 5 solid outer shell lines.

Fixings you'll need:

M4x60 screws (2pcs)
M4x25 screws (4pcs)
M4 locking nuts (6pcs )
Washers (optional)

Printed in both PLA and E3D EDGE, works fine.
28mm scale astro warrior miniature torso

title: Quad TC-R antenna holder, The Minimal and The laughing Gremlin

description.text:
This is an updated version of my previous antenna holder which can be found here

I recently figured out that cotton bud straws are also another good alternatives for RX antennas as they are pretty stiff and they don't get damaged nor deformed that easily. However I bumped on two different sizes of thickness. 2.5mm and 2.8mm of diameters.

The stl file contains both the Laughing Gremlin and the Minimal version in three varieties:

  • 5mm hole for a regular straw.
  • 3mm hole for a tight fit of the thicker cotton bud straw (will also fit the smaller one)
  • 2.8mm hole for a tighter fit for the thinner cotton bud

Hope you enjoy and happy flights!

Edit: Sorry for the lack of a 3D Preview of any of those files but it is either me who did something wrong when exported these .stl files (which I can print with no issues) or thingiverse needs some more time for these files to be able to be previewed. Any advice on this would be much appreciated.

description.text:
This is a graph of a function proportional to the electric potential in the neighborhood of four charges sitting on the corners of a square.  The function is z(x,y)=((1-x)^2+(1-y)^2)^-1+((1-x)^2+(1+y)^2)^-1+((1+x)^2+(1+y)^2)^-1+((1+x)^2+(1-y)^2)^-1.  
Twenty years ago I couldn't even print out a quality image of this function since therer were no lasers that could spool an image that big, so I ended up printing to a fax machine.  
flow was xls>dat>scad>stl>skp>stl with one netfabb repair and some cropping.  
Shout out to thomthom and his shell extension for sketchup: i wouldn't have succeeded in less than 24 hours without it.
Walls are thin, so two shells makes it solid.  I had some pulling, but you should be okay if you've covered your machine or have fans going.  No support needed if printed at given ratio of scales.

comments.text: Great models, thanks for sharing!  It is worth noting that "employee_dual_2" is non-manifold, which causes issues with Simplify3D when slicing.  I repaired it with Netfabb, and it seems to have fixed the issue.  Without repairing, Simplify3D will have plastic printing twice (both colors) in certain areas.  This caused my initial print to pop off the bed near the neck (where this issue occurred).  Will reprint with repaired model soon.  Thanks again!

description.text: aphex

Well folks, this is a remix of a remix.

I came across this fantastic design (adapted from SexyCyborg's Wedge Sandal) and thought to myself that it was a real shame that the original remixers hadn't bothered to make a left shoe when they unleashed their voronoizers on this Thing. After all, most of us, with the exception of Cinderella, require two shoes to make our escape from grabby princes at royal balls.

All I did was use the MeshMixer mirror function to create the left shoe. I also generated a file with both the shoes for those of you lucky enough to own a printer with such a large print volume.

Dual extrusion version of my original Low-Poly Darth Vader. This time he is not alone... Pink Vader is with him!

This model is divided in two/three parts. There are different versions (Darth Vader or Pink Vader, with and without cape). As all my low-poly designs, it doesn't need support material to be printed (I consider support material an evil creation of the Dark Side adepts).

I hope you enjoy with this model and may the force be with you!

title: Raspi IR Cam Mount for Prusa i3 mk2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have created a case for the raspi IR cams (those with the bigger lenses).

It will fit on the same holder as in the original design and require 4 M3 screws and nuts to connect the front and back together (I like screws and even if they aren´t needed - it´ll make the final item look very cool).

Since the "Ball Style" wears out pretty quick and will make the cam move (or tip over) I´ve created a new mount which will use screws to fix it all together.
I used a m3x25 and a self locking nut to mount the camera and a self tapping 3x10 screw to fix the coupling to the base. By loosening and tightening the screws you can adjust the camera and make this much more reliable then the ball mount.

Be gentle with the self tapping screw this will wear out the plastic if you remove it to often or screw it to hard. I´ll make a version with a regular M3 screw and an inserted nut. btw. the M3 screw i used was in the spare pack of the prusa i3 mk2 kit.

Yes i could get rid of the ball "fitting" but it will work for both mounting styles so i´ll keep it as it is. The base bar is straight - simply because the camera was interfering with the print head and it also needed to be further away for a better picture.

See the attached rendering and picture for assembling instructions.

I´ll provide a print all at once stl too (no supports needed - if you need a raft depends on your printer - since this is designed for the prusa i3 mk2 I´d recommend printing it directly to the PEI surface).

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This was printed with an awesome new PLA filament which I´m currently testing. Can´t tell you more - but I´ll update this info when I can talk about it ;-)

the base can be printed as is - the coupling should be printed upside down (the squareish part facing the build plate)

title: Harris 3/4" 3m Decorating pole Universal 'U' Hook Attachment (For hard to Reach Christmas Lights)

description.text: I needed to reach the high branches of our tree to hook some christmas lights around it. I found this truly universal 3m extending painting pole from Harris in our garage, it had a 3/4" 5 Tooth per inch thread. So I decided to design and make hook that would screw directly onto the top to allow you to lift the Christmas lights up and over tall branches. And as it's Christmas decided to share it with you all- hope you find it useful for something.! - Fusion 360 file included to if you want to tweak etc.

title: Another ball mount (Ram Mount style) for Action Cam

description.text:
About the projec ... it's very easy to print and mount.
Take a look to the picture (especially the position in the printer plate) and u cannt make mistakes.
I suggest to print at 0.15 mm.

To complete a good work and to have more grip i suggest to print in ABS and after paint the ball (only the ball) with some nial polish.
If u use PLA or other (not acetone solvent) then paint the ball with rubbery paint.

title: Subaru Legacy BH5 LINK ASSEMBLY-WINDSHIELD WIPER
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mail me if you need it please. I`ts for free.

86510 MOTOR & LINK ASSEMBLY-WINDSHIELD WIPER
Part number 86521-AE000 & 86521-AE030

20.01.2018 ReEdited Nut
29.01.2018 Adapted size m18x1.5x9 (repaired).stl (ABS)
05,02,2018 Added model with shroter screw (should be stronger)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

90%

Notes:

Actually ifill could be in 20-80% it does not matter cause in thicker wall 1mm.
I recommend to use Nylon material, Pet-G, SBS
Normally I scale model to from 100% to 101.6% when using Nylon. Scale only in screw axys not length.

comments.text: Works great in multiple Subarus, installed on 2001 Forester S... worked great vs all the dorman replacement pieces that last a few weeks/months at best.
comments.author: Linuxglobal

comments.text: Thanks digiTALker, great design, better than the original part. Easy to install. I had this made on 3dhubs in fdm nylon 100 micron at 50% infill and then fitted to an Impreza MY99 at the wiper motor connection. I did not use the ring nut. Installation tip if you install this part - once the motor bolts are removed, remove the motor link arm from the motor (12mm retaining nut).
comments.author: tangles

comments.text: Same here, wasnt sure what the large diameter nut was for, had to file down the 2 halves a little bit to get the thread correctly. Used 100% inflil for max strength and possible gear down over time of the abs.
comments.author: tangles

comments.text: It was my mistake. I fixed it two days ago.
comments.author: Linuxglobal

author: producer989

title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

description.text:
Generate your own nuts, bolts, washers and threaded rod by simply typing the required parameters into customizer. Great for replacing metal equivalents in many applications such as the ROLLER RING | Universal Filament Spool Holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:176442.
Includes options to generate WingNuts for easy hand tightening and removal. Now includes socket cap, socket button and socket countersunk head types with support for socket, phillips and slot drives.
You can also join threaded rod to form unlimited lengths by creating a custom extended joiner nut.
Uses the PolyScrewThread library from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796 NEW Updated version 6/3/2016: added extended options to control number of facets on nuts, square sockets (or any number of facets) and socket depth control. NEW Updated version 1/1/2017: modified library code to remove dependence on deprecated 'assign' statement.

comments.text: I printed the nut and bolt (in Matchbox PLA) as one of my first projects on my new printer. I wanted the nut/bolt for my desk and scaled it up 200% in Cura (2.3.1) so people could handle it. The parts came out absolutely great even on medium quality with no supports. The threads are nice and clean, no sanding necessary. I did find that the nut is pretty loose on the threads though. Is this due to shrinkage in PLA or is was it my fault in scaling all three axes 200%?
comments.author: DestroyerofFilament

comments.text: It really depends on your printer tolerances, speed, cooling etc.regarding how tight you can make the fit. For an 8mm bolt, a gap of 0.8 mm (8.8 inner nut diameter) seems to work well for most. That translates to a 10% tolerance, but that is not proportional to scaling. In other words, the gap should not need to change, regardless of scale.
comments.author: DestroyerofFilament

comments.author: mike_mattala

comments.text: OpenSCAD preview mode is bit buggy for example, difference calculations where the object subtracted has the same dimension value as the object it is subtracted from, often causes display anomalies.  In some of my designs I have added small values eg. 0.001mm to fix display anomalies when using preview mode (f5) to render with OpenCSG, rather than the full CGAL render (f6). Customizer also uses an older version of OpenSCAD.

comments.author: kferg55

comments.text: We're looking at some lazer/epoxy printer models for fine detail stuff. There's one on the market that is quite affordable, but the "ink" is not so affordable. So it would be perfect for the screws and other tiny bits. here's an example on youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=snOErpOP5Xk This tech is pretty new but expect it to really take off in the next while. It's efficient, high detail, pretty plastics, and very compact for the home market. It's just pricey for the photosensitive polymer "inks." Teamed with a cheaper filament printer, you would be quite versatile.
comments.author: kferg55

comments.text: There are some techniques to try to print smaller objects.  The main issues are cooling and the thread step angle.  Most printers struggle with a step angle less than 45 degrees, but you can improve results by optimising cooling. Even for ABS, cooling fans can be used effectively on small objects.  Also try slowing the print speed and printing multiple objects at the same time.  This ensures there is plenty of time for cooling between layers and the print head does not  spend too much time directly over the object, effectively overheating it.

comments.text:
A very excellent generator. I just used it to make a 3/8-16 bolt with a through hole for a tripod time lapse rig I've been working on.
I stumbled through the metric to sae conversion a little, mostly because the terms are different.
So to save anyone else the trouble, all you need to change is
thread_outer_diameter (major diameter)
thread_step (pitch or TPI or threads per inch)
step_shape_degrees from 45 to 30
inch:mm conversions for threads can be seen here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unified_Thread_Standard

author: producer989

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kMOUdLcK9LM

This think makes it easy to add a baffle around your Rostock MAX printer. Print multiple copies and snap-link them together. Make a ring for the top and bottom. Cut a piece of poster board or other thin (0.5 mm or thinner) sheet and slip into the slots. Since it is a ring it is self-supporting even with very thin materials.

In the example photo I'm using a laminated panoramic photograph. It has a clear border around the photo so you may not see the plastic.

There are two STL files, one with a continuous arc and one that has been cut up. After too many prints pulling up on the ends I cut up the arc to relieve the stress. It works, but I like the continuous version better. You may want to consider a raft if the parts peel up on the ends during the print.

description.text: Designed for pinchers. Drill with 3mm to get accurate hole and add some glue to keep it in place.

To save energy in my night sessions of programming i constructed a little lamp, which can be attached to the back of my Cherry keyboard without screws or glue.

So i must no more switching on my big light and i have no more reflexions on my monitor.

I have integrated a little switch.

For voltage i have opened my keyboard case und implemented an USB-connector for 5V voltage. But you can use any USB on your desk or from any computer.
I am using a warm white LED-stripe made for 5V. Please use single LEDs and no RGB LEDs because of the limitation of 100mA of an USB-Port.
Attention: Many white LED stripes are 5050 types, that means the white light is mixed of RGB-LEDs, which need more current electricity than an USB port should deliver!

The light can be spinned arround its horizontal axis, so you can set the area of light on your keyboard.

Have fun in the dark night :-)
Fan of pacman?
Holder for KIDs bed side guard

description.text:
I wanted an arcade machine and everywhere i looked, people wanted money. So i made one myself.

it used;

+ (official) 7" raspberry pi touch screen

+ Raspberry Pi 3

+ Adafruit Joystick - 8-Way Arcade Joystick

+ Official Sanwa Arcade Buttons - 2 of eack colour

+ 2 cheap 65mm speakers i had laying around the tinkering cupboard. (optional)

+ USB extension cable (to add games)

+ MicroUSB extension cable (for power)

I prototyped it in 3.2mm (1/8") plywood, and will be doing it in acrylic as a final product.

Uploaded in 2 different flavours. ai and dwg. will upload a video once finished cutting on monday.

Added ESC and F1 button on the right side and start and select on the main face

To avoid any scrutiny,

DISCLAIMER:

This is a completely ORIGINAL make, meaning that, though there are many of these out there, with the exception of the Raspberry Pi and Screen images, which were downloaded from the sketchup 3d warehouse, the rest is 100% drawn without any outside digital/CAD files of any kind.

comments.text: I looked at your files. They are one big file. Do you think you could split them into printable parts?
comments.author: cbitterfield

comments.text: So i have been trying to sort this out, only to realized the bottom and back pieces are larger than 8x10"
comments.author: cbitterfield

comments.text: Hello! An industry standard for laser cutters is 600mm x 400mm and all acrylic we buy is in that size. Though i can tear them down. The ".ai" file is very easy to edit if you have Adobe illustrator.
comments.author: cbitterfield

description.text:
Designed for a Skywalker but would work fine on a variety of airframes. Requires 4x M3 bolts long enough to go through the fuselage of your plane for mounting, and 2x small zip ties. You'll also need some wheels!

The zip ties are designed to allow you to quickly replace the landing gear if they break, or hopefully allow the zipties to snap and save the gear (and your fuselage) in the event of a hard landing.

Check out my blog at www.thedoble.com

Thanks for stopping by!
If your multi has bad bearings, or slightly unbalanced props, you'll notice that the camera is shaken around quite a bit. This can ruin both the audio and the video.

This is what you need! It uses 3 of FliteTests Vibration dampening bobbins: to isolate the Mobius camera from the frame.

It uses a T-shaped bolt pattern 18x35mm, where 2 bolts are 18mm apart, and the third 35mm away, centered between the first. The top plate can be zip-tied to the rest of the assembly, or use velcro straps if you want a removable option. Just be sure it's tight, so you don't let it rattle. :)

Nothing beats the smell of fresh baked bread. But getting the bread safely out of the Breadmaker mold can be a challenge, avoiding fingers getting burned in the process.
I made this Breadmaker release key to make the process easier - use it to rotate the kneading insert and loosen the bread.

I made two key sizes, select the one that fits your Breadmaker (Inner size for small is 36mm and for large is 43mm).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

2 perimeters, 3 top and bottom layers.
The shown keys are made in PLA, but ABS or PET-G will withstand the heat better.

comments.text: I have a breadmaker like this and I tried to print the release key, but unfortunatly after the horizontal is printed the model seems to bend and one side comes loose, and the print fails. Can you give me a hint? Printing in PLA on an Original Prusa i3 MK2s.
comments.author: Johan87

comments.text:
Sounds like it is an adhesion problem.
I would try cleaning the bed with acetone to make sure there is no grease on the surface before printing (cool bed).
If the print still fails, add a brim to the print - this will keep the print on the bed. The brim is easy removed after printing with a sharp knife.
comments.author: Johan87

comments.text: Thanks for the tip, never thaught I would be so happy with aceton :-)
comments.author: Area51

comments.text:
Acetone is great for real cleaning the hot bed and isopropyl alcohol between prints (and Windex for PETG)... :-)
Measurements is now added to the description.

title: Durable & Comfortable Cigarette Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In search of a gift to print, I found many smoker's rings on this site, but upon printing, they were found to be very flimsy and very utilitarian. Since it would only require a few shapes, I decided to make my own, and this was the result. I feel that it is stronger and more comfortable than the others I have found.

The inside diameter is roughly 16mm, so it is quite small. I may make a larger one later.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Printing this without supports is possible, but a small file (<10mm diameter) may be needed to smooth the inside of the cigarette holding clip. I made mine on an Ultimaker 2.0+, but it should work on pretty much any 3D printer.

Tinkercad

Two toroids, a box connecting them, and two subtraction boxes to make the cut-away for the cigarette clip.

title: From Failure Comes Knowledge Maker Coin

description.text:
3D Printing is a hobby in which one should not be afraid of failure. The fails are going to happen and through that failure, through the despair and struggle, the re-tweaking of settings, comes knowledge.

This Maker Coin embraces the fails we all encounter in our 3D Printing journey. It features a silhouette of 3D Benchy, complete with a big old spaghetti mess of a fail at the crown.

The phrase, "Ex Deliquo, Cognitio" borders the coin. The sentiment---from failure, knowledge.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Blender

I designed the coin in Blender. For the Spaghetti, I am using Bezier Curves with a square as the Bevel Object. The sphaghetti is unsupported in places with the hope of provoking variation and real "micro fails" in the print. I was very much inspired by "Drooloop" Jelly Fish and Flowers by Mark Peeters (http://www.thingiverse.com/peetersm/about), but I wanted variation and chaos, so I used curves.

author: Toddwats001

description.text:
This is a set of Glass Corners for Prusa i3 which allow you to place a piece of transparent glass above the aluminium bed. With this, the aluminium bed with RepRap logo is clearly visible and it is a beautiful sight. Suitable for PLA Only machines which does not require a heat bed for printing. Cover glass with kapton tape and apply a diluted layer of glue before printing. Print object will stick firmly onto glass surface. Print a pair of Corners_Slotted.stl and a pair of Corners_Fixed.stl
The slotted version allow you to adjust the position of the corner by 5mm so that it matches the position of the glass.

description.text:
Jig to use a drill press to cut 8mm rods. Not shown in the pictures; I added a bearing between the bottom housing and the drill press plate hole ring, there is a cavity for this. Otherwise, you'll need a couple of screws and fairly rugged springs.

I’ll eventually need to cut 6mm rods, so will add those files when I build that jig.

In the mean time, please share if you adjust for other sizes, thanks!

1) Be careful (safety gear please) and be patient (took about 5 minutes to cut a 8mm
chrome rod)
2) Place your rod into the jig.
3) Place the rod into the drill press, tighten chuck.
4) Attach the jig to the drill press plate.
5) Adjust the height of the drill press plate to just below your cut line.
6) Insert the blade.
7) Affix a wooden block to the drill press plate to keep the blade from flying out
(otherwise, it will!)
8) Raise the drill press plate so that the blade is on your cut line.
9) Spray on some lubricant.
10) Pull the blade press back and start the drill press.
11) Release the blade.
12) Lubricate every minute or so.

title: Printrbot Simple (Early 2013) Direct-Drive Extruder 30mm Fan Mount

description.text: I was concerned about melting filament at the direct-drive extruder hob, because of the heat from the extruder stepper. This printed part replaces lasercut part E1 on your Printrbot Simple direct-drive extruder. It allows you to bolt on a 30mm fan that can move air past the direct-drive extruder, keeping it cool. The new part provides 4 holes for self-tapping screws, and a wider opening to provide a direct air path. I used this $8 fan: http://tinyurl.com/p62fxpb Works best with the early 2013 Printrbot Simple. Compatible with the Early 2013 and Late 2013 models. Not compatible with the early 2014 Printrbot Simple.

The fan was wired to the 40mm cooling fan in parallel, so it turns on whenever cooling is enabled by the gcode. In hindsight, I probably should have just spliced into the 12v source with it.  
The 4 extruder mount screw holes were made a bit deeper, as my screws were unable to reach through to the stepper. I have included the SketchUp file so you can chance the part as needed.  
I find that while the fan keeps the direct-drive hob completely cool, it doesn't do much to keep my undersized stepper cool (I'm using a shorter stepper than what is included with the official Printrbot kits).

Also, my extruder motor isn't the one that Brook includes with the kits, it's the same size as the rest of the motors on the 'bot.

remixed_from.author: deckingman
remixed_from.title: Another Duet WiFi Enclosure with Fan

description.text:
This version of "Duetwifi and duex2/5 enclosure 1.3" is an improvement on 1.2 and resolves a few issues and provides more selection options in the scad file.
With the duex2/5 selected the fan is a 40mm model and fitted internally or externally onto the side of the enclosure in order to blow cool air between the 2 boards. With just the duetwifi a fan of 40,50,60 or 80 mm can be selected and is fitted internally or externally in the rear of the enclosure.
The lids are fixed by using self tapping screws.
Cables are attached through cable slots at the rear lower part of the enclosure.

The scad file includes a choice of the following:-
Duetwifi no fan
Duetwifi 40/50/60/80 external fan mount
Duetwifi 40/50/60/80 internal fan mount
Duetwifi and duex2/5 no fan
Duetwifi and duex2/5 40/50/60/80 external fan mount
Duetwifi and duex2/5 40/50/60/80 internal fan mount
fan guard 40/50/60/ fan widths

select printbox to print enclosure
select printlid to print main enclosure lid
select printlidx5 to print lid for duex5 board
select printguard to true to print grill
select nuttrap for the grill to have nut traps or round head bolts
select expcon to include access to the expansion connector of the duetwifi board

select hardware to view boards and fans in position
select assembled to view the complete enclosure with lid/s

boards are bolted using M4 15mm bolts
The mounting holes are located to fit to a 20 or 40 mm profile at a right hand corner but can easily be changed.
Note:- print support is needed, especially for the duex5 version

comments.text: I can't find a lid that fits Duetwifi_50_fan_internal_enclosure_v1-3.  They are all too big.  Tried scaling it down, but then the lid screw holes are just a tad off.  Guess I'll have to redesign the lid to fit.

comments.text: its a monoprice mini
comments.author: 3DanielDesigns

comments.text: Huh... I spent countless hours calibrating, understanding gcode, tweaking Cura, reading, testing, reading some more, giving up on 3D printing for weeks at a time, then coming back to try and have either the print lifted half way and mangled or the print finished but with a horrible first layer. I also have a Monoprice mini and the only way I can print is with raft. Prints come out decent, but only with the raft. Also, the raft adheres great onto regular blue masking tape. Which makes me ask, how come the "first layer" for the raft works just fine, but the first layer of the object printed does not. Is it the printer, Cura or me? The raft works, but it wastes time and material.
comments.author: Nak4000

comments.text: The raft could be the problem. You shouldn't need one for this. You're printing a large base then trying to print something intricate on top of it. You need to get a good "first layer" adhesion going on this and you should be fine. If it is pulling up there is something wrong with your first layer. A heated bed if you have one, if not use a glue stick. Get that sucker down good and after about 3 layers you should see everything staying on and working fine. Heated bed/Glue works best in my testing. It's a bit messy and a pita to clean off but it works so I do it. Just note, you do not have to put glue down every time. Just once in a while when the "stickiness"  goes away. When the layers of glue build up to a noticeable height you'll need to use alcohol and get it off with a scraper. You can watch YouTube videos for this removal.
comments.author: modemman

comments.text: I am new at 3D printing as well but I found that if you use heated bed, it is best to apply a sheet of regular glass of 3mm, you can then apply Kapton tape and with a dish washer sponge (rugged side) and some CIF cream you can rub it to take off the shine of the tape, this gives very good adhesion. You can also apply the Kapton directly on the aluminum plate but it will take you longer to take off the prints. If it's on glass, you remove the clips, throw it under cold water (or freezer) and in 5 mins you are back printing. This is the cleanest method I found so far and works every time, with PLA at 65 degrees C and ABS at 105 degrees.
comments.author: modemman

comments.text: Thanks. I'll go source glass, everyone says so. Is it easy to reset the Z axis "zero" point after adding extra thickness? Also, the stock aluminum bed is a bit warped (concave), so I can never get a good calibration.
comments.author: elfhelm

comments.text: Cheapest solution is to look on Aliexpress for replacement bed and a glass. More expensive is to buy BLTouch and adapt it to your machine. Good luck!
comments.author: modemman

comments.text:
The reason your prints lift without a raft is the upper layers Pull the first layer up
when there is a raft, the first layer has a better bond to the bed & will not lift as easy...
You can also try using a Glass sheet on top of your bed, just google it, and then use a painted on solution of 1 part cheap wood glue & 5 parts water.
This should be cleaned 7 re-applied once in a while, like every few prints or when ever you notice it having open spaces...
I had the same problem until I switched to Glass, Good luck!!!
comments.author: modemman

comments.text: Thanks. Glass seems to be the universal answer. It's just frustrating that I got a few great prints (spinners) for a few days in a row, then one time I had to leave the printer for an hour or so and I came back to a big blob of melted plastic being dragged around. I never got a good print ever since.

title: 6 to 14mm sleeves for toilet seat fitting

description.text:
Just a quick copy of a missing toilet seat fitting which disappeared while fixing my toilet. Luckily I had my 3D printer to save the day. I hope someone else appreciates this little piece of plastic as much as I do.

For some reason my printer always makes holes smaller than they are modeled so I had to run a 6mm drill through this after printing. You might have to do the same.

title: Heavy Mendel, a self replicating 3D printer/mill/PCB engraver

description.text:
The design is inspired by the triangular frame of the reprap Mendel, It will be heavier and more rigid to be able to mill plastic, engrave circuit board and print at high speed. Differences compared to the standard Mendel :
  • vertical X axis to quickly change the tool (extruder or spindle)
  • M10 and M12 threaded rods instead of M8 for better frame stiffness
  • 10mm smooth rods instead of 8mm for better axis stiffness
  • Precision doubling belt configuration inspired by Madkite's design : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8852
  • nema23 steppers for the X and Y axis instead of nema17
  • Each axis will be equipped with 4 printed linear bearings : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16946
    • I will also try to use steel cables instead of timed belts for X and Y axis. All parts are printed with 0.2mm layer height. Work in progress. [edit]
    I've uploaded the different parts on several "things" for more clarity :
    Main/Frame : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19368
    X Axis : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25975
    Y Axis : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25976
    Z Axis : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25978
    Linear bearing : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16946

comments.text: Have you thought of using the Mendel Max frame for more rigidity?  Also, do you have a blog or something.  I would be very interested in following the progress of this project.
comments.author: Apologue

comments.text: I like to design my own stuff :)
comments.author: Apologue

comments.text: I like your ideas, Im working on an all rounder myself, I decided to go with the conventional CNC router look over the mendel.. Have you thought about using threaded rod for all axis instead of steel cables. They should give the machine enough strength to cut alloy's. you already have the bigger steppers, which helps with the torque issue. I wouldnt mind sharing ideas, and come up with a simple and strong all rounder CNC. Maybe something worthy enough for Kickstarter..

comments.text: Threaded rods are way too slow for 3D printing and I don't think the frame is rigid enough to cut aluminum precisely.

author: Petrus

description.text:
Trátase dun aparcadoiro cun número limitado de prazas. Un display 7 segmentos indicará o número de prazas que quedan dispoñibles.

Hai un barreira de entrada e unha barreira de saída. A detección de coches á entrada e á saída faise con sensores ultrasónicos e o movemento das barreiras con servos. Cada barreira consta dun único sensor ultrasónico á entrada: cando detecta un obxecto sobe a barreira e cando deixa de detectar o obxecto agarda un tempo e baixa a barreira.

Cada vez que entra ou sae un coche un contador rexistrará o cambio.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the fan-duct with the plate to screw the fan on in direction to the heat bed. Also 8mm brim

description.text:
I made this thing, because the standard sled overhangs so much. In my version the hot-end is as near to the 2040-profile as possible. To achieve that, I had to extend the base plate from from 7cm to 9cm, to fit the hot-end between the two front-rolls.

So please notice: You will lose 2cm of workspace in the x-axis! (1cm at each side)

The longer sled makes it also more stable and less wobbly, which is quite nice.

There are two versions of this. The first (x_sled (base+fanduct).stl) is one stl with the base plate and the fan-duct combined. The second version is x_sled_base.stl and x_sled_fan-duct.stl seperatly. Version 1 is most likely a lot sturdier, but version 2 is easier to print. For Version 2 you nead two M3-screws to connect the fan-duct with the base-plate.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed the fan-duct with the plate to screw the fan on in direction to the heat bed. Also 8mm brim

description.text: My dad had a magnifying glass where the handle broke so I made this replacement one. I utilized the customizable handle below for the grip. author: ocw617

print_settings.Notes:: Recommend printing in Nylon. I use Taulman 910 for all drive train components.

description.text:
This is a locked central differential that is a drop-in fit into the original OpenRC central differential housing. I made this to help increase the strength and reliability of the drive train. NOTE: the gear itself has been modified for the same reason, and is a mod .9, so the original pinion gear (mounted on the motor shaft) is not compatible, so I've included a mod .9 version here as well. I haven't printed this yet, but I have printed a mod .9 version of the normal differential assembly and it stands up really well.

UPDATE: 06/19/07
New Centre Diff printed and running great and the new gear pitch is holding up to the abuse.

Update 06/20/07
By request, 0.8 Mod 57 Tooth Version added.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Recommend printing in Nylon. I use Taulman 910 for all drive train components.
